On Apr 28, 2007, at 12:28 PM, afcarl2 wrote:

> (c) I'm not sure I communicated my question adequately. To point,
> activation functions w/ more than one parameter, not just an
> operation on the summation of the inputs to the node. I believe this
> would require either evolved parameters associated with the
> implemented activation function for a given node, or the ability to
> maintain unique multiple inputs, each of which perform a summation of
> the conntected inputs to a given unique input. Is this stated any
> better?

This is simply implemented, such that whenever you add a new node,  
it's given some random parameters.

However, I believe your adding unnecessary complexity in doing this  
(or even in supporting multiple activation functions) -- effectively  
increasing the size of your search space.  But, I haven't researched  
the learning performance difference.

--Steve
--Apple-Mail-2--228810143
